<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">Four isostructural transition metal-based MIL-53 anologues, [M(ntd)(e-urea)] (M = Mn, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; Co, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; Zn, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>; Cd, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>; ntd = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate; e-urea = ethyleneurea), are urothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), elemental analysis (EA) and Infrared Spectroscopy (IR). The results of TGA and PXRD for these isostructural compounds show that they exhibit distinct thermal behaviors, where the Zn- and Cd-forms are much easier to lose the ligated e-urea molecules from the frameworks than the Mn- and Co-forms. The CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> sorption properties and photoluminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were also investigated.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Four isostructural transition metal-based MIL-53 anologues, [M(ntd)(e-urea)] (M = Mn, 1; Co, 2; Zn, 3; Cd, 4; ntd = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate; e-urea = ethyleneurea), are urothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), elemental analysis (EA) and Infrared Spectroscopy (IR). The results of TGA and PXRD for these isostructural compounds show that they exhibit distinct thermal behaviors, where the Zn- and Cd-forms are much easier to lose the ligated e-urea molecules from the frameworks than the Mn- and Co-forms. The CO2 sorption properties and photoluminescent properties of compounds 3 and 4 were also investigated.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The rational synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted considerable attention because of their structural diversity and potential application in catalysis, gas storage and separation etc. . Chemical synthesis of MOFs is largely dependent on the use of solvents, and the well-known synthetic methods include hydrothermal, solvothermal and ionothermal synthesis . Recently, urothermal synthesis that use urea derivatives as solvents opened a new approach toward the creation of porous framework materials with promising applications . One particular feature of urothermal method is that urea derivatives exhibit a range of binding affinity for various metal cationic sites, which is strong enough to allow them to bond competitively to metal sites during crystallization, and yet weak enough to be readily removed after synthesis to generate porosity and open metal sites.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted considerable attention because of their structural diversity and potential application in catalysis, gas storage and separation etc. . Chemical synthesis of MOFs is largely dependent on the use of solvents, and the well-known synthetic methods include hydrothermal, solvothermal and ionothermal synthesis . Recently, urothermal synthesis that use urea derivatives as solvents opened a new approach toward the creation of porous framework materials with promising applications . One particular feature of urothermal method is that urea derivatives exhibit a range of binding affinity for various metal cationic sites, which is strong enough to allow them to bond competitively to metal sites during crystallization, and yet weak enough to be readily removed after synthesis to generate porosity and open metal sites.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">One critical point associated with the generation of open metal sites is how to keep the framework stable . So far numbers of stable porous MOFs with open metal sites (such as HKUST-1, MIL-101, MOF-74 etc) have been reported, which demonstrated the possibility to get stable coordination unsaturated metal centers in the framework structures . However, the detailed factors related to the framework stability are still unclear and need more studies, because the bonding geometry of unsaturated metal centers might shift to result in changed frameworks. Thus, understanding on the correlation between framework compositions and thermal behavior becomes highly desirable, especially for the framework materials prepared from urothermal procedure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: One critical point associated with the generation of open metal sites is how to keep the framework stable . So far numbers of stable porous MOFs with open metal sites (such as HKUST-1, MIL-101, MOF-74 etc) have been reported, which demonstrated the possibility to get stable coordination unsaturated metal centers in the framework structures . However, the detailed factors related to the framework stability are still unclear and need more studies, because the bonding geometry of unsaturated metal centers might shift to result in changed frameworks. Thus, understanding on the correlation between framework compositions and thermal behavior becomes highly desirable, especially for the framework materials prepared from urothermal procedure.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Herein, we report the urothermal synthesis, structures and properties of four new coordination polymers: [M(ntd)(e-urea)] (M = Mn, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; Co, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; Zn, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>; Cd, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>; ntd = 1,4-Naphthalenedicarboxylate; e-urea = ethyleneurea), by using ethyleneurea hemihydrate as solvent. The most interesting point of this work is the distinct thermal behavior presented by four isostructural compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. The Zn- and Cd-forms can breathe out the ligated e-urea molecules at related low temperature; however it is difficult for the Mn- and Co-forms to lose e-urea. The reason for such difference is analyzed and discussed by considering the detailed bonding nature of these compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report the urothermal synthesis, structures and properties of four new coordination polymers: [M(ntd)(e-urea)] (M = Mn, 1; Co, 2; Zn, 3; Cd, 4; ntd = 1,4-Naphthalenedicarboxylate; e-urea = ethyleneurea), by using ethyleneurea hemihydrate as solvent. The most interesting point of this work is the distinct thermal behavior presented by four isostructural compounds 1-4. The Zn- and Cd-forms can breathe out the ligated e-urea molecules at related low temperature; however it is difficult for the Mn- and Co-forms to lose e-urea. The reason for such difference is analyzed and discussed by considering the detailed bonding nature of these compounds.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and instrumentation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. The thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a TA Instruments SDT Q600 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under the flowing nitrogen atmosphere.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Materials and instrumentation

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. The thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a TA Instruments SDT Q600 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under the flowing nitrogen atmosphere.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">General Method for the Preparation of Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>: M(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·xH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.5 mmol), 1,4-Naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (ntd, 0.1000 g, 0.5 mmol) and e-urea hemihydrate (2.0 g, 20 mmol) was sealed in a 20 ml vial and heated to 120 °C for 3 days. After washed by water, suitable crystals for X-ray diffraction were produced.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: General Method for the Preparation of Compounds 1-4: M(NO3)2⋅xH2O (0.5 mmol), 1,4-Naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (ntd, 0.1000 g, 0.5 mmol) and e-urea hemihydrate (2.0 g, 20 mmol) was sealed in a 20 ml vial and heated to 120 °C for 3 days. After washed by water, suitable crystals for X-ray diffraction were produced.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">For <ce:bold>[Mn(ntd)(e-urea)]</ce:bold> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), colorless needle crystals were obtained (0.1462 g; yield: 82%, based on Mn). Element analysis: calcd. C 50.72, H 3.41, N 7.89; found C 51.27, H 3.39, N 7.82. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3276(w), 3060(w), 1594(s), 1476(w), 1384(s), 1073(w), 920(w), 785(w), 648(w).</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Single-crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Suitable single crystals of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Single X-ray diffraction intensities of all crystal were collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K. All diffractometers were equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo-K<ce:italic>α</ce:italic> radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods and expanded with Fourier techniques. Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using the SHELXTL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and the hydrogen atoms bound to carbon were located by geometrical calculations and their positions and thermal parameters were fixed during the structure refinement. All calculations were performed with SHELXL-97 package. Pertinent crystallographic data and structural refinements for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal structure determination

Suitable single crystals of compounds 1-4 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Single X-ray diffraction intensities of all crystal were collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K. All diffractometers were equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods and expanded with Fourier techniques. Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and the hydrogen atoms bound to carbon were located by geometrical calculations and their positions and thermal parameters were fixed during the structure refinement. All calculations were performed with SHELXL-97 package. Pertinent crystallographic data and structural refinements for 1-4 are listed in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Simple urothermal synthesis were performed by mixing different metal salts, naphthalenedicarboxylic acid and ethyleneurea hemihydrate in the vials at 120 °C for 3 days. Four kinds of crystals (compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) were obtained and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, respectively. Interestingly, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are isostructural and exhibit similar structural feature as the well-known MIL-53 .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Simple urothermal synthesis were performed by mixing different metal salts, naphthalenedicarboxylic acid and ethyleneurea hemihydrate in the vials at 120 °C for 3 days. Four kinds of crystals (compounds 1-4) were obtained and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, respectively. Interestingly, compounds 1 to 4 are isostructural and exhibit similar structural feature as the well-known MIL-53 .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">All structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> feature infinite chains of corner-sharing MO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra linked by the ntd ligands to generate one-dimensional rhombic channels along the a-axis, which can be considered as MIL-53 analogs (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>a–b). Unlike MIL-53, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are all transition metal-based structures, where the ntd ligands and neutral e-urea ligands replace the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate linkers and the bridging <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-OH unit in MIL-53, respectively. Several Mn-based MIL-53 analogs using pyridine <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-oxide and its derivatives as neutral <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> ligands have been reported recently . The difference from them is that the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-e-urea ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> come from the solvent directly, so it is much easier to control the reactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: All structures of 1-4 feature infinite chains of corner-sharing MO6 octahedra linked by the ntd ligands to generate one-dimensional rhombic channels along the a-axis, which can be considered as MIL-53 analogs ( a-b). Unlike MIL-53, compounds 1-4 are all transition metal-based structures, where the ntd ligands and neutral e-urea ligands replace the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate linkers and the bridging μ 2-OH unit in MIL-53, respectively. Several Mn-based MIL-53 analogs using pyridine N-oxide and its derivatives as neutral μ 2 ligands have been reported recently . The difference from them is that the μ 2-e-urea ligands in 1-4 come from the solvent directly, so it is much easier to control the reactions.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In the structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the 1-D channels are blocked by the e-urea ligands, and no other guest molecules are found. To create pores from the structure, removing the ligated e-urea ligands becomes the only choice. Since each metal center is coordinated by four different ntd ligands and two e-urea ligands. The removal of the e-urea ligands from the framework should make each metal center generate two unsaturated sites. That gives more challenge for the framework stability.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the structures of 1-4, the 1-D channels are blocked by the e-urea ligands, and no other guest molecules are found. To create pores from the structure, removing the ligated e-urea ligands becomes the only choice. Since each metal center is coordinated by four different ntd ligands and two e-urea ligands. The removal of the e-urea ligands from the framework should make each metal center generate two unsaturated sites. That gives more challenge for the framework stability.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were investigated under the flowing nitrogen atmosphere (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). Unusually, they exhibit two kinds of thermal behavior. The TG curves of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> only show one platform from room temperature to 370 °C, then the ligand decomposition makes the whole framework totally collapse. In comparison, there are two obvious platforms in the TG plots of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. For <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, The first weight loss of 24% from 280 to ca. 330 °C corresponds to the full liberation of e-urea molecules (calcd: 23.6%), and the remaining framework [Zn(ntd)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> shows no weight loss up to ca. 400 °C. The compared powder X-ray diffraction patterns further confirm that the framework [Zn(ntd)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> does not change at 300 °C, but it shifts to an unknown phase after full removal of the e-urea ligands at 350 °C (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). The total solvent-accessible volume of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is estimated to be 34.9% using the PLATON program . The TGA curve of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is similar to that of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, but <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> has higher thermal stability than <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. As demonstrated by the powder X-ray diffraction patterns, the framework of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> does not change at 350 °C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds 1-4 were investigated under the flowing nitrogen atmosphere ( ). Unusually, they exhibit two kinds of thermal behavior. The TG curves of 1 and 2 only show one platform from room temperature to 370 °C, then the ligand decomposition makes the whole framework totally collapse. In comparison, there are two obvious platforms in the TG plots of 3 and 4. For 3, The first weight loss of 24% from 280 to ca. 330 °C corresponds to the full liberation of e-urea molecules (calcd: 23.6%), and the remaining framework [Zn(ntd)]n shows no weight loss up to ca. 400 °C. The compared powder X-ray diffraction patterns further confirm that the framework [Zn(ntd)]n does not change at 300 °C, but it shifts to an unknown phase after full removal of the e-urea ligands at 350 °C ( ). The total solvent-accessible volume of 3 is estimated to be 34.9% using the PLATON program . The TGA curve of 4 is similar to that of 3, but 4 has higher thermal stability than 3. As demonstrated by the powder X-ray diffraction patterns, the framework of 4 does not change at 350 °C.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Why they have such distinct thermal behavior is worthy of mention. Since Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> have close ionic radius, the M–O bond lengthes with the e-urea ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are also similar (average <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">Mn</ce:inf>
<ce:inf loc="post">–</ce:inf>
<ce:inf loc="post">O</ce:inf> = 2.271 Å, <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">Co</ce:inf>
<ce:inf loc="post">–</ce:inf>
<ce:inf loc="post">O</ce:inf> = 2.211 Å, <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">Zn</ce:inf>
<ce:inf loc="post">–</ce:inf>
<ce:inf loc="post">O</ce:inf> = 2.224 Å). Thus, this might not be the primary reason for their distinct thermal behavior. It is notable that e-urea forms two N–H⋯O hydrogen-bonds with two adjacent carboxylate oxygen atoms in each structure (a). The average N···O distances in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are 2.801, 2.745, 2.758 and 2.850 Å, respectively. The hydrogen bonding interactions in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is slightly weaker than in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, but stronger than in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. This result indicates that the possible reason from hydrogen bonds could not explain too.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Why they have such distinct thermal behavior is worthy of mention. Since Mn2+, Co2+ and Zn2+ have close ionic radius, the M-O bond lengthes with the e-urea ligands in 1-3 are also similar (average d Mn - O = 2.271 Å, d Co - O = 2.211 Å, d Zn - O = 2.224 Å). Thus, this might not be the primary reason for their distinct thermal behavior. It is notable that e-urea forms two N-H⋯O hydrogen-bonds with two adjacent carboxylate oxygen atoms in each structure (a). The average N⋅⋅⋅O distances in 1-4 are 2.801, 2.745, 2.758 and 2.850 Å, respectively. The hydrogen bonding interactions in 3 is slightly weaker than in 2, but stronger than in 1. This result indicates that the possible reason from hydrogen bonds could not explain too.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The other difference between the metal centers in 1–4 is about the d orbital electrons. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, both Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions have unpaired <ce:italic>d</ce:italic> orbital electrons, whereas both Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>-blocked. Once the e-urea molecules were removed, the coordination number of the M<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> center would be reduced from 6 to 4, and the octahedral geometry should change to planar quadrangle, correspondingly. At the current stage, it is still unclear whether the <ce:italic>d</ce:italic> orbital electrons should affect the departure of the e-urea molecules or not. Anyway, such two kinds of distinct thermal behavior in 1–4 must be closely related with some detailed chemical properties of the metal centers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The other difference between the metal centers in 1-4 is about the d orbital electrons. In 1 and 2, both Mn2+ and Co2+ ions have unpaired d orbital electrons, whereas both Zn2+ and Cd2+ ions in 3 and 4 are d10-blocked. Once the e-urea molecules were removed, the coordination number of the M2+ center would be reduced from 6 to 4, and the octahedral geometry should change to planar quadrangle, correspondingly. At the current stage, it is still unclear whether the d orbital electrons should affect the departure of the e-urea molecules or not. Anyway, such two kinds of distinct thermal behavior in 1-4 must be closely related with some detailed chemical properties of the metal centers.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gas adsorption measurements of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> at 273 K performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer were investigated, which further confirm the porosity in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Both samples of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were activated under vacuum at 300 °C for 2 days, respectively. A significant increase in the amount of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gas adsorbed by each sample was observed as with an increase in the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> pressure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>), indicating the diffusion of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules into the channels. The CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake at 1 atm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were 6.7 cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g and 13.6 cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g, respectively. The higher CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake capacity of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> than that of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> may be due to the higher framework stability of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The CO2 gas adsorption measurements of 3 and 4 at 273 K performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer were investigated, which further confirm the porosity in 3 and 4. Both samples of 3 and 4 were activated under vacuum at 300 °C for 2 days, respectively. A significant increase in the amount of CO2 gas adsorbed by each sample was observed as with an increase in the CO2 pressure ( ), indicating the diffusion of CO2 molecules into the channels. The CO2 uptake at 1 atm for 3 and 4 were 6.7 cm3/g and 13.6 cm3/g, respectively. The higher CO2 uptake capacity of 4 than that of 3 may be due to the higher framework stability of 4.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0095" view="all">The solid state photoluminescent properties of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> have been investigated at room temperature. Both compounds exhibit similar intense fluorescent emission bands with peak maximum at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 400 nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 425 nm for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> upon excitation at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 350 nm (). Considering the natural photoluminescent property of the free ntd ligand , the emission spectra of both compounds may be attributed to an intraligand emission state.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The solid state photoluminescent properties of 3 and 4 have been investigated at room temperature. Both compounds exhibit similar intense fluorescent emission bands with peak maximum at λ = 400 nm for 3 and λ = 425 nm for 4 upon excitation at λ = 350 nm (). Considering the natural photoluminescent property of the free ntd ligand , the emission spectra of both compounds may be attributed to an intraligand emission state.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">In summary, four interesting isostructural transition metal-based MIL-53 analogs with distinct thermal behavior are synthesized urothermally, which reveal unusual correlation between framework compositions and thermal behavior.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, four interesting isostructural transition metal-based MIL-53 analogs with distinct thermal behavior are synthesized urothermally, which reveal unusual correlation between framework compositions and thermal behavior.

General Method for the Preparation of Compounds 1-4: M(NO3)2⋅xH2O (0.5 mmol), 1,4-Naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (ntd, 0.1000 g, 0.5 mmol) and e-urea hemihydrate (2.0 g, 20 mmol) was sealed in a 20 ml vial and heated to 120 °C for 3 days. After washed by water, suitable crystals for X-ray diffraction were produced.

For [Mn(ntd)(e-urea)] (1), colorless needle crystals were obtained (0.1462 g; yield: 82%, based on Mn). Element analysis: calcd. C 50.72, H 3.41, N 7.89; found C 51.27, H 3.39, N 7.82. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3276(w), 3060(w), 1594(s), 1476(w), 1384(s), 1073(w), 920(w), 785(w), 648(w).

For [Co(ntd)(e-urea)] (2), pink crystals were obtained (0.1520 g; yield: 85% based on Co). Element analysis: Calcd. C 50.16, H 3.37, N 7.80. Found C 50.04, H 3.40, N 7.75. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3397(s), 3106(w), 3072(w), 1610(s), 1517(s), 1453(s), 1384(s), 1302(s), 1238(m), 1187(m), 1048(s), 829(m), 770(m), 657(m), 577(m), 532(m).

For [Zn(ntd)(e-urea)] (3), colorless block crystals were obtained (yield: 0.1241 g, 68% based on Zn). Element analysis: calcd. C 49.27, H 3.31, N 7.66; found C 49.31, H 3.49, N 7.85. IR (KBr pellet, cm -1 ): 3376(w), 3067(w), 1620(s), 1498(m), 1383(s), 1066(w), 1027(w), 786(m), 752(m).

For [Cd(ntd)(e-urea)](4), colorless crystals were obtained (0.1630 g; yield: 79% based on Cd). Element analysis: Calcd. C 43.66, H 2.93, N 6.79. Found C 43.54, H 3.08, N 6.65. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3397(s), 3106(w), 3072(w), 1610(s), 1517(s), 1453(s), 1384(s), 1302(s), 1238(m), 1187(m), 1048(s), 829(m), 770(m), 657(m), 577(m), 532(m).

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). The total solvent-accessible volume of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is estimated to be 34.9% using the PLATON program . The TGA curve of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is similar to that of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, but <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> has higher thermal stability than <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. As demonstrated by the powder X-ray diffraction patterns, the framework of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> does not change at 350 °C.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gas adsorption measurements of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> at 273 K performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer were investigated, which further confirm the porosity in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Both samples of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were activated under vacuum at 300 °C for 2 days, respectively. A significant increase in the amount of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gas adsorbed by each sample was observed as with an increase in the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> pressure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>), indicating the diffusion of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules into the channels. The CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake at 1 atm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were 6.7 cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g and 13.6 cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g, respectively. The higher CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake capacity of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> than that of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> may be due to the higher framework stability of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">The solid state photoluminescent properties of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> have been investigated at room temperature. Both compounds exhibit similar intense fluorescent emission bands with peak maximum at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 400 nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 425 nm for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> upon excitation at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 350 nm (). Considering the natural photoluminescent property of the free ntd ligand , the emission spectra of both compounds may be attributed to an intraligand emission state.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds 1-4 were investigated under the flowing nitrogen atmosphere ( ). Unusually, they exhibit two kinds of thermal behavior. The TG curves of 1 and 2 only show one platform from room temperature to 370 °C, then the ligand decomposition makes the whole framework totally collapse. In comparison, there are two obvious platforms in the TG plots of 3 and 4. For 3, The first weight loss of 24% from 280 to ca. 330 °C corresponds to the full liberation of e-urea molecules (calcd: 23.6%), and the remaining framework [Zn(ntd)]n shows no weight loss up to ca. 400 °C. The compared powder X-ray diffraction patterns further confirm that the framework [Zn(ntd)]n does not change at 300 °C, but it shifts to an unknown phase after full removal of the e-urea ligands at 350 °C ( ). The total solvent-accessible volume of 3 is estimated to be 34.9% using the PLATON program . The TGA curve of 4 is similar to that of 3, but 4 has higher thermal stability than 3. As demonstrated by the powder X-ray diffraction patterns, the framework of 4 does not change at 350 °C.

The CO2 gas adsorption measurements of 3 and 4 at 273 K performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer were investigated, which further confirm the porosity in 3 and 4. Both samples of 3 and 4 were activated under vacuum at 300 °C for 2 days, respectively. A significant increase in the amount of CO2 gas adsorbed by each sample was observed as with an increase in the CO2 pressure ( ), indicating the diffusion of CO2 molecules into the channels. The CO2 uptake at 1 atm for 3 and 4 were 6.7 cm3/g and 13.6 cm3/g, respectively. The higher CO2 uptake capacity of 4 than that of 3 may be due to the higher framework stability of 4.

The solid state photoluminescent properties of 3 and 4 have been investigated at room temperature. Both compounds exhibit similar intense fluorescent emission bands with peak maximum at λ = 400 nm for 3 and λ = 425 nm for 4 upon excitation at λ = 350 nm (). Considering the natural photoluminescent property of the free ntd ligand , the emission spectra of both compounds may be attributed to an intraligand emission state.

decomposition temperature.type: unknown phase after full removal of the e-urea ligands
